paragraphs.text: You don’t have to be an entrepreneur to solve problems. When you work in sales, you solve problems. If you’re an accountant, you solve problems. And so forth.
But solving real problems also reaps the biggest rewards. That’s why I always like to ask myself with everything I do: What problem will this solve?
You either solve problems for clients or for your boss, colleagues, stakeholders. You see? Life is a series of answered problems.

paragraphs.name: 7faa
paragraphs.text: Last year I decided to start a podcast. I had no idea where to start, so like everyone else who needs information about a subject, I went to Google.com for some answers.

paragraphs.name: fee5
paragraphs.text: “People think free information is a big deal. But it’s still free information. That means it’s either garbage or it only provides you piece of the puzzle.”

1177ac359424.title: I’ve been studying how and why I need to improve my design studio the past few years.

paragraphs.text: I’ve been studying how and why I need to improve my design studio the past few years. Every bit of research leads back to this answer but never this clear. Thank you, very good piece.

724a7645016a.title: This is what I have struggled for last couple years.

paragraphs.text: This is what I have struggled for last couple years. You don’t have to quit your works to become entrepreneur, you don’t have to quit your life to do startup. Core of doing startup/becoming entrepreneur is giving solutions for problems. As long as you’re solving problems, you’re doing “startup” in your way.

paragraphs.text: That was your first mistake. You should have gone to DuckDuckGo, hit the blogs in the Deep Web Google hides and cross-referenced with Flipboard articles.
